descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Baron Davis and Jamal Mashburn scored 22 points each, and all five of Charlotte's starters reached double figures Wednesday night in the Hornets' 97-90 victory over Miami.

related.description:
The Charlotte Hornets exceeded all the requirements set by the NBA for a move to New Orleans, team owners
announced Wednesday.
related.linkText: Hornets say they've met requirements for move
related.title: Hornets say they have exceeded all requirements
related.headline: Hornets say they have exceeded all requirements

related.description:
For the first time in 20 years as an NBA coach, Pat
Riley won't finish the season with a winning record.
related.linkText: Riley suffers through first losing season in 20 years
related.title: Best fading Heat can finish is 40-42
related.headline: Best fading Heat can finish is 40-42

article.headline: Hornets still alive for homecourt advantage
article.linkText: Hornets deal blow to Heat's playoff chances
article.story:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Jamal Mashburn claims the Miami Heat are just another team to him. The Charlotte Hornets think otherwise.
Mashburn

Mashburn scored 22 points, including two critical baskets down the stretch, to keep Charlotte in the thick of the playoff race with a 97-90 victory over the Heat on Wednesday night. "Anytime we play them, he wants to punish them," said Charlotte guard Baron Davis, who also scored 22 points. "He always wants to be the guy to put the dagger in them, to throw the knockout punch. He comes out with a pretty strong focus when Miami is on the floor." Mashburn, who spent four seasons with the Heat before being traded to Charlotte before the 2000-01 season, insisted his focus is the same for every team. Maybe, but he had to take satisfaction in draining a 3-pointer as the shot clock expired late in the fourth quarter, then following it with a layup that gave the Hornets a 91-82 lead. "Ever since I came back, I've had the mindset of being the guy that put us over the hump," said Mashburn, who missed 42 games this season with an abdominal strain. "All this, it's just part of winning. Of course you want to play well against guys you suited up with for four years, but we just need to win games and that's all there is to it." Former Miami teammate Alonzo Mourning disagreed, going as far as saying Mashburn never contributed consistently when he was with the Heat. "Of course he gets up to play us, he's a totally different player against us," Mourning said. "If he had played this way when he was with us, I bet he'd still be with us." All five of Charlotte's starters reached double figures as the Hornets continued their chase of homecourt advantage in the playoffs. They're in a three-way tie with Milwaukee and Philadelphia for fifth place in the Eastern Conference and trail Orlando by 1½ games for the fourth spot. Jamal Magloire had 18 points and 11 rebounds, David Wesley scored 16 and P.J. Brown had 15 points and 13 rebounds. Davis also had 10 assists. Miami lost for the seventh time in its last eight games and is in 11th in the East. The Heat fell to 32-42 on the season, guaranteeing Pat Riley his first losing season in 20 years as a head coach, but Mourning said they haven't given up on the playoffs yet. "You always have a chance until you are statistically out of it," he said. "Until the numbers say we are out, we'll keep fighting to get in." Eddie Jones led Miami with 27 points. Mourning had 14 points, Brian Grant had 12 points and 11 rebounds and Eddie House also had 12. The Hornets blew a 10-point lead in the third quarter, allowing Miami to take its first lead since early in the first quarter when House tossed up a 3-pointer that hit the rim, bounced up and circled around before falling through to make it 65-64 as the buzzer sounded on the third quarter. Miami pushed its lead to 69-64 but could never pull away from the Hornets and their hot shooters. "We were right there again tonight and we let it get away from us again," said Riley. "We have to overcome something every night and tonight it was their shooters." Game notes
Miami's LaPhonso Ellis and Brown were selected divisional winners for the 2001-02 NBA Sportsmanship Award. ... Charlotte forward Lee Nailon missed his second straight game with the flu. ... Center Elden Campbell returned to the team following a five-game absence and had five rebounds and no points in 11 minutes for Charlotte. He missed the first game with a hamstring injury and the other four because his father died. ... Starters Kendall Gill and Rod Strickland scored just eight points each.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
